Expectation1: Offer help or support when asked
Situation1: An acquaintance asks for a recommendation on a good restaurant in the area.
Situation2: The cleaner discovers the client is completely out of a specialized cleaning product that is essential for the next task.
Story: I was just finishing up dusting the living room shelves when I heard my phone buzz. It was Mia, someone I’d met at a community event last month. “Hey! You know the area well, right? Can you recommend a good restaurant for my parents’ anniversary?” she texted. As an acquaintance, I felt I should reply quickly and thoughtfully, maybe even look up a few options to help her out. But as I glanced at the cleaning cart, my heart sank—I’d just realized we were out of the special wood polish Mrs. Lee insisted on for her antique table, and I was supposed to clean it next. I knew she’d be upset if it wasn’t done today, and it was my responsibility to keep track of supplies. My mind raced, torn between wanting to be a helpful friend and needing to fulfill my duties as a cleaner. I stared at my phone, feeling the pressure of both roles closing in, unsure which demand to answer first.
